I can't say that I agree that it is any kind of a disaster that we need to worry about when old ruins from our own misguided building and exploitation of an area goes bad.  Man created the original disaster in the first place by erroneously diverting the river, then foolheartedly built "the Riviera" and now it seems depressing that it's reverting back to its original state.  Sure there'll be a few "gloomy" decades (very subjective and very anthro-centric viewpoint) while nature reclaims the area.  I see it as totally natural and our brief 100-200 year pimple on the landscape as nothing lost as it reverts.  Sure, a few false human-dreams were crushed but they were unwarranted in the first place - there never were going to be the conditions to have a permanent Eden here - it was a short-lived situation that the water was fresh enough to be pleasant for us Humans.  Nature is fine with cleaning up after us.  We should be fine with her being fine.

You really should have Googled Salton Sea before you made this video. The Sea, as it dries up, is becoming a HUGE problem in more more ways than one. The unimpeded salty dust whipping across the salt-flat is hard on living things and deposits on crops, better farm land, etc. Imagine strong, dry, salty, dirty wind smacking you in the face a whole bunch. Or trying to grow a crop downwind. The Sea also tricks creatures (birds, bugs, reptiles...) into showing up only to find only salty brine.

- The dry lake bed sends up dust storms of toxic particulate matter and ozone, leading to asthma, cardiac disease, lung cancer, and increased mortality rates
- There is a proposal to import seawater from the pacific ocean with a canal twice the length of the Panama canal

What he doesn't say is that the valley is actually, geologically, the north end of the Gulf of California. Baja California is sliding north along the San Andreas Fault, and the Salton Sink is part of the split. It was once continuous, and full of ocean water.

The trick is that the Colorado River comes in at the side, and it dumped the entire Grand Canyon of sediment as a delta in the gulf. That reached across and cut off the Salton Sink, which dried up. There is sea salt under the Salton Lake.

The second trick is that rivers meander, and the Colorado would sometimes go south to the sea like it does now (except all the water is taken for irrigation), and sometimes would go north into the Salton Sink just like accidentally happened.

I think the Sink had just finished a drying cycle when Europeans arrived.

Anyhow, there is more salt under there than you might think, and this has happened before. That doesn't make it any less our fault and our responsibility.

This is my back yard. I live about 10 miles away. They have spent HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS of dollars STUDYING the problem and so far, not one single dollar fixing the problem. To me it is simple. cut off a section from fresh water that flows in. Turn that area into evaporation ponds. Harvest the minerals for commercial use. Let the fresh water go into the rest of the Sea and let it start coming back. Reducing the mineral level this way will also help the birds that use it, reduce the algae bloom that takes up the oxygen and kills the fish, and make the whole thing a healthy resource again.
But, believe it or not, the environmentalists think that's a bad idea. I'm an organic farmer, and a huge advocate for the environment. What possible reason could you NOT want to clean it up?.... sigh.
There is another proposal that could also work. bring in a canal from the Gulf of Mexico and add ocean water to it. While that will raise the water level, it is still a viable solution.

This is the least amount of research and the most amount of false info I’ve ever seen put out about the Salton Sea.
The salton sink already existed when the dam broke that’s why the water was diverted there.
It’s not “near” the San Andreas Fault .. the fault ends dead ass in the middle of the sea.
Towns didn’t suddenly appear in the 50s/60s, they were already there. Marketing helped bring in Hollywood elite & their friends to vacation there which gave rise to yacht club and other vacation spots on both shores.
The Sea doesn’t continue to exist only because of farm water run off. The New River, which flows inland from Mexico into the US, dumps into the sea. The river is highly toxic & polluted with sewage from Mexico plus the farm chemicals from the US & Mexico.
The sea is also toxic af because the US govt used it as an atomic bomb testing site.
The sea has a higher saline to water ratio than the Dead Sea does. Despite this, nature has adapted, and life continues to flourish in the sea.
I’m also going to point out how dangerously stupid getting that close the mud pots is. The ground there is incredibly unstable.

Regarding the ecosphere in general, I fully agree we need to use the utmost respect in shaping the environment. But many environmental efforts require global coordination, and it will take time before that become commonplace.
One last thought... Our planet do alternate between glacial periods and warm periods, because of the influence of all the water and the air. My back-of-the-envelope calculation is that the thermal equilibrium temperature, without the presence of an atmosphere, is -20 °C, due to the Sun radiance less the heat reflected in space. The temperature is controlled by water vapor and C02 in the air, and the planet seems to have its ideas on the level of the global temperature, notwithstanding all our efforts to reduce the emissions of C02.
Rather than a blind effort to try to control the global thermostat, maybe a global scientific effort to understand and measure all the complex processes that are going on in recycling the carbonates in the Earth core, the volcanic emissions, the role of life - from cyanobacteria to humans, from algae to the taller trees; a global picture with numbers, I believe would help more than anything else.

Been there. The fish bones were so high along the shore and the stench so bad, it was hard to see beauty in the lake. But hey, it's a short drive to some beautiful mountains near there, and it was in those mountains that I proposed to my wonderful wife of 19 years! The desert view below provides a gorgeous contrast to the mountain scenery. I love the Salton Sea area... from a distance.

That area used to be the northern most point of the Gulf of California.  The delta of the Colorado River eventually blocked that area off from the rest of the gulf.  There were a couple times thousands of years ago when the CO River flowed into it instead of the gulf, making it a lake/sea, but that eventually changed; leaving the inland sea to dry into a basin.  It’d take some sort of massive change to make it a natural lake again, or human intervention.  The latter happened by mistake.  There really isn’t a good reason to reroute the CO River to there again, especially considering that it’s loaded with chemicals from farm runoff and the high salt content.

So, what should be done about the Salton Sea? He says, "if we don't care, if we don't put in any effort, it's not going to turn out well". But if we do care, if we put in the effort, well, the effort to do what?

One option is to pipe ocean water to the Salton Sea, so that it maintains a constant water level, and becomes saturated with salt. Salt crystallizes and settles out, as fast as new salt arrives. Another is to divert fresh water to it, so that it maintains a constant water level with minimal additional salt. But minimal isn't the same as none. And salt isn't the only thing that arrives. It gets agricultural runoff, full of everything that gets sprayed on and everything that leaches from the soil and subsoil.

The answer that seems obvious to me is to bring in water, either ocean water or fresh water or some of each, but also to pump water out. That water would be poured out on the ground not too far away, somewhere that's already a salt flat: an area that had salt water evaporate as an ancient, larger version of the Salton Sea dried up. The salt flat would still be a salt flat, the Salton Sea would still be good habitat for a wide variety of birds, the organic pesticides would be broken down by exposure to sunlight, and the toxic elements leached from subsoil would be sequestered in the salty soil of the flat.

"The cost of restoring the Salton Sea is nothing compared to the human health, ecological, and economic impacts of letting it dry up. It's also a crucial habitat for a huge variety of migratory birds and a key stop within the Pacific Flyway. Humans have decimated almost all of the remaining wetland habitats throughout the state. We can save the Salton Sea, revive the region, and stop an impending health disaster by connecting sea to sea through Coyote Canal." - @Derrick Ruthless. Imagine what a tourist attraction a healthy Salton Sea could become if a canal big enough for riverboats and cruise ships was dug between the Gulf of Baja and the largest freshwater lake in California. Aside from tourism, the region has potential to become a renewable energy powerhouse and a real estate goldmine. The Imperial Valley is rich in wind, solar and geothermal resources. Floating solar panel power plants could slow the sea's evaporation rate. Integrated Pumped Hydropower Reverse Osmosis systems could use excess renewable energy to desalinate water and pump it up into mountain reservoirs. When power is needed, reservoir water is released to spin the pumps and their electric motors backwards to generate power. RO Brine could be discharged into evaporation ponds along the rapidly drying southern end of the sea for suppressing dust and cultivating brine shrimp for raising fish to restock the sea. This area is where 544 megawatts of geothermal power is already online and an estimated 2,000 megawatts of geothermal energy awaits development. Warren Buffet's company may be in talks with Tesla about harvesting lithium from the geothermal brine. If the state and federal governments committed to such a plan, these investors would be more likely to get off the fence and pull the trigger on the projects they've planned. Reimplementing the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) and the Works Progress Administration (WPA) would provide meaningful work opportunities to unemployed and underemployed people and pay off dividends in the future. The Salton Sea was created by nature. Many irrigation techniques have been used for thousands of years including the technique that was used on the Colorado River in 1905. It was the over flooding of the river that caused the breach. Over rain on the river’s watershed. The basin that the sea now resides had a salt mine in it.  The salt came from somewhere. There was a sea there before. I’m sure when it evaporated there was some YouTube guy telling the cave men that this was all a mistake and that something should be done.

The Salton Sea used to be part of the Gulf of California, which went all the way to Indio. The Colorado river is very silty and created a delta which became a land bridge which sealed off that part of the Gulf to become Lake Cahuilla/Salton Sea. https://youtu.be/BKsK13NDkpg?t=101 (time linked to this animation)

Because of this massive delta the Colorado River then took turns (every few hundred/thousand years) either filling the Salton Sea, or when it was full and overflowed like a bathtub, it would reform the Colorado River which would once again drain into the Gulf of California. It is not simply an engineering accident that resulted from the damming/damning of the Colorado River.

Given that our civilization and the dam in question will probably not last 10,000 years, there may be or will almost assuredly be a version of the Salton Sea once again, even if our civilization chooses not to save the current iteration, though untold bird populations will die if we don't, since it is a major bird nesting/replenishment habitat.

The are maps of this and abandoned camps, fish traps and much  archaeological evidence . it is not a question of "If" the salton sea should exist, but a question of when should it exist. you see, the depression that holds the salton sea was part of the sea of cortez until the colorado river changed course and started emptying into the sea of cortez south of where the salton sea is now. before that, the colorado river emptied much further north and into the pacific ocean. once the river started emptying into the sea of cortez, it began to create a delta, very much like the Mississippi river delta but in the enclosed tip of the sea of cortez the delta built up and eventually closed off the salton sea from the sea of cortez. then over time as the colorado river meandered about it would sometimes dump into the sea of cortez or sometimes dump into the salton sea. back then without human interferance, when the river dumped in to the salton sea it would often fill it to slightly above sea level. then after a while (geologically speaking) the river would shift and dump back in to the sea of cortez. then with no major in flow, the salton sea would be gin to dry out. this was a cycle that happened many times.

in modern times humans have tried to control the rivers. to protect from flooding and to send water to areas it would not have naturally flowed, for irrigation and domestic use. one action was to dike the colorado river to prevent it from naturally changing course and flooding the salton sea. but then as described in the video we forced water in what we thought was a controlled manner into the basin and it got away from us.

so in short, yes, the salton sea should exist, it was there before we were and on more than one occasion. quite possibly it was there before the area was inhabited by humans. and before it was the salton sea, it was part of the sea of cortez.. the history of the salton sea is an amazing geologic story. i encourage you to google it and learn more. things like the name of the basin it is located ot, the "salton sink" the name of old prehistoric lakes in the same spot like "Lake Cahuilla" the lake has been known to the natives and fish traps are still left over near old shore lines.

I like this video but disagree with your conclusion. There are indeed plenty of examples where human created "ecosystems" like this one that were created in a relatively short timescale (50 years is nothing on an ecological scale) indeed require constant human intervention to keep them that way. Without it, indeed chaos tends to arise and the ecosystem changes drastically. But this is also true for any "natural" ecosystem. There too, if you zoom in far enough, chaos seems to increase constantly. The sheer complexity of those ecosystems though, ensures that massive changes in one factor (species) are often countered by  changes in another species. The end result is that ecosystems in the sort term, because climatologic and geologic parameters change very slowly, tend to have its biological components gravitate towards a stable state (or equilibrium) that resists change. See Scheffer et all if you're interested. In the long term, those systems will change though and a real equilibrium doesn't exist in the way often portrayed in movies and documentaries as if all species are smart enough to adhere to certain  rules. In the sort term, enough biologic parameters in any system seem to ensure that the increasing chaos in one parameter are likely compensated by changes in other parameters. A lake like this, with very few species initially, and especially species that didn't belong there in the first place, will show enormous swings that will slowly subside until enough species are there to  create a sort of temporary stable state. If you look at the lake in a 100 years for instance, you might find a very interesting saltwater lake full of shrimp and flamingos and many migratory birds feeding on them. Or maybe a completely different ecosystem because of factors I can't even think off. If we keep moving the goal posts though, the system will keep changing rapidly, until some factor is able to counter the chaos we keep introducing in the system.
Left to themselves, things tend to go from bad to worse. / murphy's law /

At 5:50 the narrator says “In the absence of our caring, things tend toward disorder; things naturally fall apart.”  That may be true of human things—plans, structures, desires, intents—but not necessarily natural things, like deserts and lakes.

We know (from geological evidence) that the Salton Sink has filled and emptied many times over the past few thousands of years: sometimes it was a dry desert basin, and sometimes a lake; sometimes the lake was freshwater and sometimes salty.  So, the natural order seems to be what is happening right now: a lake that was created by accident is being erased again by natural processes.  Human intervention—building resorts, adding fish, fertilizing crops upriver, etc.—was the source of the disorder that we see now, a disorder that is slowly being returned to the natural order, without further human intervention.

Perhaps the lesson to be learned is that nature rules, and that our human desires and intents must always yield to the natural order.  A temporary lake deserves temporary structures and short-term plans, and we should be prepared to see them all evaporate, when the time arrives.

There can be no order without chaos, no good without evil, no light without darkness. Humanity mainly strive for order but in its quest to do so is destroying itself with chaos. What must we do? How should we move forward? When will it end? All good questions and the answer will always start with you.

Adopting a more temporally inclusive perspective, human action is irrelevant. There have been multiple major extinction events in Earth's history, and the evidence suggests that each of these was associated with enormous environmental change.

I agree that we as a species should be more responsible, but we must also be pragmatic. There are many things one might conclude we need to care about, and while the Salton Sea may be symbolic of our species imperative to be more responsible, it may not be the best example for us to focus our limited time, and resources.

As an example, you have probably never heard of White Nose Syndrome and because of the ecological role that bats play by consuming large quantities of flying insects, my initial stance would be that understanding WNS and mitigating it should be of much more obvious importance than a salty, toxic lake in California with some derelict structures around it.

The dead sea in Israel is a sea that has already gone through all those salt levels and has reached a level where people will come to visit it and go into it and enjoy floating on top of the water without needing to keep themselves up by swimming.. The argument over whether or not we should 'allow' the lake to dry up, is really over. The reason is that the water is very polluted and thus the sand under the lake is very polluted. Agricultural runoff has been a major contributor to the pollution and increasing salinity of the sea and now it has created a serious health concern as the waters have receded. We already observe increased rates of asthma in adjacent areas. If the lake bed is allowed to be exposed, lots of contaminated soil is going to be blown all over populated areas. We have polluted the water, the polluted soil and now we have only one real solution. That solution is to refill the sea. The best option is likely to dig a canal from the Gulf of California to the Laguna Salada, West of Mexicali and then continue a canal or pipeline, across the US/Mexico border, to the Salton Sea. The best, but not surprisingly, the most costly option, would be simply letting the sea fill to sea level and allowing the in-flows and out-flows to reduce the salinity to match that of the Gulf of California. Trouble here is you'd be flooding other populated areas and having to re-route or rebuild entire sections of I-8 and I-10 to cross the sea. You would reduce the pollutants over time as the water is exchanged with the Gulf of California. You'd also have the option of an inland seaport if you build the canal wide enough and deep enough.

A more reasonable option might be to simply fill the lake with the same canal/pipeline solution, but keep it low enough to simply cover the polluted lakebed that has already been exposed. This has the drawback though, of not reducing the salinity much and leaving no avenue of escape for the polluted water.
Or, you could build a pipeline over the Peninsular Ranges east of Carlsbad. You'd only have to pump the water to the top and let gravity carry the rest over down to the Salton Sea. You no longer have to negotiate with Mexico to do this, but the same drawbacks apply. The water doesn't have anywhere to go, the salinity won't drop much over time and the pollutants stay.

Just a few additional comments: 1. The ancient lake that used to be there intermittently is called Lake Cahuilla. There is a much smaller lake of that same name near La Quinta. 2. Before the Salton Basin was flooded, there was a huge salt harvesting operation at the bottom. There is legend that there is still a train locomotive under water there. 3. The northern Sea of Cortez has changed shape many times in the past and there is a legend of a Spanish pearl ship just to the south. 4. Sometimes, when the wind is blowing from east to west (Santa Ana winds) the rotting fish can be smelled in Los Angeles. 5. Over the past century, agricultural runoff with nitrates and pesticides have been filling the Salton Sea from the north. And the New and Alamo rivers have been filling the sea with raw sewage and industrial waste from Mexicali from the south. If the Salton Sea is left to dry out, it will be an ecological disaster with winds blowing dust with poisons and heavy metals, possibly into heavy population centers.

Glad you mentioned the fact that this lake is not just here because of an accident in the early 1900's.  In fact the lake is a natural phenomena.  The Colorado river has the highest silt content of any other river.  By far.  And, when left to run it's natural course it has numerous times created large dams of silt which prevented it from running out to the Sea of Cortes.  The route it takes when this happens is it diverts its course naturally and runs into the Salton sink creating the Salton sea naturally.  The Salton Sink is 280 feet below sea level.  in the past the Salton has filled up to sea level or nearly so and the old water line can be seen if you look for it.

The video misses at least 2 important issues.  The silt at the bottom of the lake contains salts and metals which would be harmful to human health if the Salton Sea goes dry.  The dust of that silt would blow around the entire region and even into Los Angeles.  Already kids who live in the vicinity of the Sea have much higher asthma rates than kids in other areas do.  So to avoid a public health hazard, the Sea should be preserved.  The second issue is the cost of remediation.  There have been engineering studies which created a plan (or several) to bring fresh water into the Sea, but that requires a source of fresh water where it's already in shortage, energy to run the pumps, and a lot of money to build and maintain the system.  No one has come up with the money.  Meanwhile, the salinity keeps getting higher. Right now, tilapia are the only fish that can survive there.  In a year or 2, not even they will survive.

Is the natural result really messy or is it simply an outcome you do not wish.  You could say a star going supernova is messy.  The supernova could destroy whole planets that could harbor life, but that supernova could also after millions of years end up producing planets or spreading elements to other planets in other solar systems that could produce new life.  The Salton Sea should be left to nature to decide, not man.  You mention there was a lake there in the past, but you gloss over the fact that it disappeared naturally.  My best guess is that the old lake vanished for many of the reasons the current one is vanishing (minus the fact that our agriculture runoff most likely sped up the process ten fold).  Letting the Salton Sea return to a natural state could benefit the area in ways that mankind couldn't even possibly imagine.  The salt, animal decay and other natural process in several thousand years could end up feeding a new life or even a new civilization, one that wouldn't or couldn't exist if we try to "fix" things now. - Whoa... after rereading my comment I was suddenly struck by the PRIME DIRECTIVE of star trek.  So to summarize my comment, in the words of the wise Jean-Luc Picard "History has proven again and again that whenever mankind interferes with a less developed civilization, no matter how well intentioned that interference may be, the results are invariably disastrous."

Sorry but I just have a few question, as I was a bit confused with the end of the end of the video haha. He said that in the absence of our care, things tend to "naturally fall apart". But I personally want to say that the aftermath of the Salton Sea area isn't necessarily a result of the predictable occurrence of things just falling apart, but our failure to look after our man-made creations, as well as our neglect, in the case of agricultural run off elevating the salt levels of the water. But I guess you can counter this by saying that, well, there is no ability for outflow to control for rising levels of salinity (since the lake is naturally already in an area of fairly low elevation). Additionally,  Derek did stress the point that things tend to fall apart due to our absence of effort and caring. I guess my only qualm would be his mentioning that everything naturally gives way to decay without us - in which case I want to answer with, "Yes, but only because you're talking about man made creations that don't have any business being there if it weren't for our intervention". The only example I can think of that goes against this (everything naturally falls apart) is the evolution of life as a result of natural selection and favorable planetary conditions. But maybe that's just luck, since I've read that the universe is slowly approaching a heat death when there will no longer be any transfer of energy available. I hope that wasn't too confusing, and I'd just love to get some feedback from someone smarter than me lol.

Yes, but caring or not caring didn't cause the Salton Sea to become salty.  I can't imagine fertilizer contains enough salt to turn fresh water into ocean water as this would routinely kill the plants the farmer was farming.  So, I doubt "not caring" caused the Salton Sea to become salty.  The salt could have come from the lake bed as the local railroad stop was called "Salton Station" in 1900 and a local creek had been called "Salt Creek" since 1867.  They were even mining salt at the time of the initial flooding.A more apt lesson is that we can control/affect a lot as humans, but we can't dictate the ultimate outcome.  We should pay more attention to what we can't control when making long term decisions, and the availability of water is something we can't typically control (at least not without a lot of effort.)  Southern California is a desert.  There will be a drought (either this one or one in the future) that will end its existence as a densely populated area, presuming a ton of desalination plants are not built (hence the "lot of effort").  If El Nino rains like in 1997 and 1998 are to fall this year, where are these rains?  A few months ago (July) the ocean temperature constituting the actual phenomena called "El Nino" looked like it did in November 1997 when the rains started back in 1997.  Aside from one downpour in July, rain isn't falling in significant quantities, and the sea temperature keeps rising.  We actually DON'T have a precedent for what happens when the sea gets this warm, and weather is the very definition of a chaotic system where slight changes in initial conditions lead to radically different outcomes (like the ever popular butterfly flapping its wings ultimately leading to a hurricane halfway around the world.)I know this isn't what you want to hear, so I will be ignored or even mocked by people whose main concern is how bad the mudslides will be.

This is why I get mad at people who claim that the Earth would be better off if we just went extinct. What they fail to realize is, even despite our apparent disorder to nature, we are still very much a part of it. We are in fact entrenched in this world, and if we were to be pulled out by our roots the results would become catastrophic. Stuff won't recover, it will only get worse.

Rather than do things that support our self destruction and absence from nature, we should promote fixing things. We should promote making things turn out for the better, ensuring that things stop being so messy. Fix our old problems before suddenly causing new ones. And most importantly we should stop being so ignorant; learn things for ourselves rather than listening to someone else who claims they know better than you tell you what to do. I can guarantee you our world will become a better place if we do so.

The ecosystem would have been better off had the humans not interfered at all, as always.
-Flooding of the area would have occurred naturally
-The place would have not been transformed into a cheesy overcrowded resort (eventually leaving shabby remnants)
-Chemical fertilizers would not have transformed the lake into a smelly soup

One could say that , by failing to maintain ecological balance DESPITE our activities, we managed to make the place inhospitable to US which is indeed a mark of foolishness, but we have no grooming duty towards nature.

In Tchernobyl, since we left, wildlife has been blooming back, and although it is a reminder that we might not be here forever, it is also a reminder that we are absolutely not essential to natural balance ; quite the opposite is true in fact.

As a geologist your wrong saying that magma is close to the San Andreas fault. It is a transition zone where the two plates are sliding past each other. Volcanoes are formed from magma which only occur at subduction zones like the Juan de Fuca (excluding hot spots). In a subduction zone the subducting plates minerals will melt at a certain depths then move upwards towards the base of the crust then slowly works its way closer to the surface. Seeing as this is on the north american plate is around 35-45km thick and no magma is present in that region.

The conclusion strikes me as being a bit of hubris tbh:

* There is no right or wrong here, only preference. Some humans prefer to have the sea, others would prefer it gone. Neither course is better or worse than the other.

* Humans can have a huge effect, but only in places where things are on the brink anyhow. We can temporarily create or drain a sea somewhere where conditions favour it, but we can't change the course of geography in the long term or affect a more established sea.

* The result of human action being messy and ugly is purely a matter of subjective taste. Some might prefer things that way.

* If a duty attaches itself to the situation, what is the duty to?

* "If we don't do anything and we don't care, then it's not going to turn out very well" for whom?

I'm totally a fan of human-cultured sustainable environments.  In its' current state, we aren't sustaining this environment.  Unfortunately this configuration doesn't look sustainable, and people have built up towns and Agriculture in the sea-level flood plain.  
This environment could be stabilized by adding (rough estimates here) about 744 cubic kilometers (1.97*10^14 Gallons) of water to the system to bring it up to sea level (This would, by the way, completely cover most of the agricultural establishments built along the current lake system).  At this point on the south end of the new lake complex, a 125 Kilometer trench/tunnel system could be burrowed south to connect to the Wagner Basin.  A combination of river diversion and tidal forces could be used to cycle the water and regulate salinity.  
This could restore the lake to the "Riviera in the desert" status, and make it more viable for agricultural and energy (the cycling of the water could be used to generate a little electricity) uses. 
Again, I am a fan of humans working with artificial systems sustainably, and I enjoy the biodiversity and agricultural applications this particular system could bring to the table, and view them as generally good when compared to the non-cultured system which existed before.

My family came to California in 1956, about the height of the effort to turn this and other inland desert areas into cheap homes for the working folk, and profits for the real estate entrepeneurs. Two other areas with some natural local water were also burgeoning, and the new medium of television then becoming widespread enough for ordinary folks to see ads like the one presented(in black and white back then for all but the rich).  California City, and Hesperia are two other near-do-well communities that did better than this one, mainly because there was no lake to get polluted nearby. The Palm Springs resort area  and the availbility of cheap air conditioners were the inspiration to these would be millionaires. That General Patton had used much of it for desert training during WWII  didn't hurt its reputation either

This area around the Salton Dry Lake, formerly mined for salt was never destined for success, however, because of the conflict with the farmers that lobbied for that irrigation system. They were their first, had first dibs on the water, and could not be convinced it was in their interest to stop letting run-off  go into the only disposal area they had available.  They also were fighting the salt build-up in their soil.

Could the land interests have found an economic compromise  of some sort that did not involve pumping sewage back up to sea level and the sea, it might have worked out for both. Of course, the Mexican government would also have to be involved, as they control the only nearby sea outlet with no mountains intervening, and right now their ag run-off also comes our way. A lose-lose-lose situation except for the geothermal resources.

I dont necessarily agree with the idea that we as humans have to do something to about this problem. Nature has had a history of balancing out and returning to equilibrium to resolve natural issues. It may be true that all the fish died due to higher salt content but those fish wouldn't have been there if we had not introduced them into that environment. Take for example where human intervention didnt necessarily work: the redwood forests. For centuries small brush fires would occur in the redwoods burning bushes and small trees but the massive redwoods remained. Now that we have nationalized the redwood forests it is our policy to stamp out any wildfires in order to "protect" the trees. But since then small trees and other plants have flourished which now compete with the redwoods for space and water which in the end hurts their growth. Im not saying for every disaster we should just sit by and do nothing, the BP oil spill would have had tremendous effects in the long run if we had done nothing but for situations like this lake I believe we should let nature takes its course.

So much misinformation. He does eventually mention that the Salton Sea has periodically flooded - every 400-500 years. Since it has no outflow the basin has gradually become salty - not from fertilizer runoff, although those nutrients contribute to the algal blooms. Between lakes it has been a dry lake bed and salt was mined there in the 19th century. The salinity of the lake, which varies depending on how much water is in it, is high because of its geologically long history of flooding and drying. The annual fish die offs are the result of algal blooms, not salinity. It will return to being a dry lake bed now that San Diego is taking the excess agricultural irrigation water that was keeping the lake full.

Salt isn't the only reason  for the fish dying in the lake. The Salton Sea is also anoxia in the bottom waters seasonally and the lake overturns bringing that anoxic water to the surface. Massive algal blooms and shallow depths cause this to be a persistent problem in the Salton Sea similar to dead zones in the oceans. If the lake dries up there is another problem besides the habitat for birds and that is toxic dust due to the salt in the agricultural run off. People still live in the area and mostly poor, a dry Salton Sea could become a major health problem for those people.

A lake below sea level with no significant supply save farm run-off and no lake run-off save through evaporation. Attempting to 'maintain' the lake, whatever that means, will require a significant freshwater inflow and outflow to keep the dissolved materials (salts etc) at a level that the local aquatic life can tolerate. That aquatic life is the baseline on which life-forms, further up the food chain can exist. This is not some pond but a significant body of water that will take no small amount of management and water-resource that the region appears not to have right now. And what exactly do we want there? Saltwater, Brackish or Freshwater? Each type will have a significant effect on the kind of aquatic life and the creatures that live higher up the food chain. Trying to save the lake from its own evolution will likely open a big can of worms. It is going to die and the best we can offer is some kind of expensive life-support.

The disorder is only happening to the artificial structures and systems. Not only the buildings but the human implanted ecosystems. The Salton Sea is going back to order with little help from the irrigation runoff that putting pesticides and salt into the lake. Nature finds a way to fix the crap we screw up.

I understand that it is a complex issue, but I do see some fantastic solutions available. Maybe you guys/gals can correct me where I am wrong.
1). Can we use the energy coming from one of the thermal plants to power a desalinization plant? The returned water would be cleaner, and the salt (if captured) could be sold or stored.
2). Return access to the Colorado river. Admittedly that river system has its host of issues already, but perhaps when it returns to a greater level of health, it can be reincorporated.
3). Carbon capture. The mud volcanoes are releasing amounts of carbon into the atmosphere right now. Can those carbon oxides be captured and stored? Is there a market for such a product? Can it be used as a fuel, or in any commercial application?
4). Soil from the banks of the lake -do they hold any commercial value? In Israel, salted soil from the Dead Sea are used in numerous applications - namely as a scrub for skin. Can there be any cosmetic value to the soil/water or is the salinity level not high enough (not of a good enough quality)?

There's deffinitly a balance needed in the amount of influence we should have in the environment around us. People forget that we too are of this earth and we can't do anything unnatural because we are natural citizens of this place. Like Derek said, this lake has come and gone many times, and we created it by accident just once out of alot of times, we were simply the driving force that triggered it that century to form. Maybe we shouldn't be so introspective of our actions and simply let them play out to our advantage and the other inhabitants of this planet will play their cards to follow. We cant save ever fish, every snail and every bird, so trying to save species that are cuter doesn't negate our impact on the ecosystem of the world. There are hundreds of species that disapear every day on this earth, species that are unique to one small hole in the ground, or one bend in a river for which there is only one representative of their kind, and then it dies. I think my point is, there are alot of things we should feel morally culpable for, but we are a species of mammals on this earth and we have a great deal of influence on it. The only way to make ourselves invisible to the ecosystem is for us all to die, so we need to accept our place, and realize that some things just aren't moral questions and sometimes we only contribute to a small part of the problem.

I think the lesson of the Salton Sea is: it's complicated.

Sometimes nature is better off without people. Sometimes it's better off with people. Sometimes it's just very different with people. And sometimes it really depends on what the people are doing in a non-obvious way.

A couple things: (1) The apparent water line around the surrounding hills.  Is that not evidence that the Salton Sea was actually part of the ocean?  Hence the initial salt content.  Also, the agricultural runoff adds more than just a salt content (which should be negligible since salt kills plants), it adds all the fertilizers and pesticides into the water polluting it further.
(2) Property cost is about $10K/lot near and around the Sea.  Activists are trying to tidy up the area to bring it back to the "paradise" it once was in the 50s-60s.  Sonny Bono played a large role in making the Salton Sea a livable place again.

Maybe it would be possible to desalinize the water with government intervention. As you said the salinity is about 50 grams per liter, but if we dropped that to about 35 grams per liter, the lake would be livable. Of course to do this you would have to effectively take another lake of the same size, but fresh water, and then dump it in. Instead of this extremely expensive and wasteful method I'm sure this could be used in conjunction with some leading desalinization processes to maybe bring the saline content back to a livable level.

With some petitioning about the ruining of the ecosystem and killing off of all those species that live there, maybe we can make them turn the place back to a paradise?

Just an idea of course, and it would obviously be way to expensive for all that, but do you think there's any way the process may be reversed? Is it really too late?

I think the salton sea has real lessons regarding ecosystem change. I'm sure the increase in birds is leading to a decrese in something else. If we only define animals, insects, bacteria or an enviorment by how benificial it is to use we miss the scientific opportunities right in front of us to study change itself. In my experience, from the disorder comes a more robust product. It holds the meaning most people feel when they say "natural". Trust that what's best, as an end result, will be. It's not the projects fault that the observer wont be around to see it completed.

Hi, firstly I really like you're videos.  You've done great work and I appreciate being able to enjoy the outcome of the effort.

Wanted to say that I think you've an interesting take on letting that lake run it's course vs. human action.  You seem to (could be misinterpreting) be saying that because people haven't done anything, the place is a mess (fingering natural chaos as the cause).  I completely agree people should clean it up, but I arrive from a different reasoning.

The agricultural runoff is human waste.  Obviously agriculture is necessary, but it is mismanaged waste nonetheless.

Or that people just abandoned those structures and vehicles, leaving them to fall apart?

Dead fish an issue?  Well, as you said, we put them there and as I argue above with the agriculture waste, we killed them.

Nature may let fish die in salty, algae infested water as well as corrode and erode structures, but that doesn't stop us cleaning up after ourselves.
